text: Amazing. Pay for the time you spend there, max 9$, with all the tea, coffee and snacks you can drink and eat for free. The decor is adorable, no music (finally!), and the staff is really friendly. It can be noisy, but if you find an empty room on the 2nd floor it's the perfect environment for working in peace. Highly recommended, it's truly a gem.
Very cool and friendly place. The cafe is spacious and bright, it's a great place to take a reading break, or have a couple hours of quiet study time in a relaxed atmosphere. It's a hidden gem!
Inexpensive, good atmosphere. Refreshing perspective from the usual café.
Wow! Très bon concept! Vous payez pour le temps que vous passez au café pour un max de 9$. Beaucoup de differentes salles! Les proprios sont vraiment gentil et le café est très bon!

Assuming you've read about the system, I'll say simply that it's a really lovely, comfortable place to spend an hour or five. Chairs for every kind of bum! Lakes, rivers of coffee! All for quite cheap.

Espace de vie que je n'aurai jamais les moyens de me payer.
C'est un grand appartement en dans le quartier des spectacles converti en café.
Ici on paie à l'heure (3$ pour la première heure jusqu'à un maximum de 9$) et on se sert un café, du thé, des biscuits....
C'est l'endroit parfait pour rédiger, corriger, relaxer....

Pour ma part j'y ai fait mon rapport d'impôts et j'ai aimé ça ...
J'adore le principe du service à volonté et de paiement à l'heure. En plus de l'ambiance réconfortante d'être assis dans le salon de sa grand-mère avec du staff super sympathique.

L'anticafé: une place où tu te sens tellement confortable que tu te croirais dans un salon !! 

Et je crois vraiment que c'est ce qu'ils ont essayé de créer comme ambiance! Oubliez le café typique des collégiens avec des sièges en bois inconfortables, des tables qui tremblotent au moindre mouvement et du café qui coûte un mois de salaire, ici tout est gratuitet moelleux à souhait (ils t'offrent même une paire de pantoufles) à condition que tu paies 3$ pour une heure avec un maximum de 9$ pour la journée! 9 piasses !!! Incroyable ! 

Bref, si tu cherches une place qui te rappelle ton propre salon, je te le conseille! 

Seul bémol, tu ne peux pas manger de repas, que des biscuits !!

Anticafe, un concept à adopter.  J'en veux plus des endroits comme cela. Je suis allée deux fois déjà. Premièrement, permettez-moi  de vous dire que le staff est superbe. Ça fesait longtemps  que je ne me sentais pas aussi bien accueilli  dans un endroit. 

Attention de bien connaître  l'adresse, sinon vous risquez de passer tout droit. L'Anticafé est situé  en plein coeur du Quartier  des spectacles sur Ste-Catherine. On peut se sentir un peu gêner d'ouvrir  la porte la première  fois, car nous ne savons pas trop si on est au bon endroit. Mais bon oui on y ait! À notre arrivée  on est acceuilli par de gentilles  personnes qui nous posent des questions  du genre, est-ce  votre première  fois? Connaissez -vous le concept etc etc. On est aussi inviter à enlever  nos grosses bottes d'hiver  pour mettre des pantoufles. Pour ceux qui ont peur de se faire voler les bottes, mes bottes  coûtent 400$ et je n'ai  pas eu peur de me les faire voler. Aussi,  si jamais vous êtes  dédaigneux  de porter des pantoufles, vous pouvez toujours  ne pas en porter ou bien apporter les vôtres. 

Alors le concept, payez pour le temps que vous restez. 3$/h jusqu'à  un max de 9$ par jour. Sur place, du café , du thé, des biscuits, des pretzels, des bonbons etc etc. Il y a aussi une machine à expresso, latte, moca qui doit être  utilisé  par le staff seulement. On nous demande simplement de laver notre tasse par la suite. Un peu comme dans une auberge de jeunesse tse. Il y a plein de salles differentes et salon sur deux étages. Vous faites  comme chez vous, même  apportez votre lunch. Il y a un micro-onde  aussi. Bref concept ben le fun.

Pas de 5*, car les toilettes  n'ont  pas de lavabo  pour ce laver les mains et que ça ferme à 11h :(

J'adore le concept! Petit café un peu caché sur St Catherine, pas loin du Starbucks, au 1e et 2e étage, avec 11 salles, dont certaines à thèmes (jeux de société, TV,..), où les gens peuvent venir pour se retrouver, étudier, travailler, etc..
Le concept c'est de payer à l'heure (3$ la 1e heure, 2$ l'heure suivante, pour un maximum de 9$ par jour), et tu as accès à du café et des petits biscuits tant que tu veux
Les taxes et pourboires ne sont pas inclus dans ces prix
Il y a aussi des activités récurrentes durant la semaine
Le staff est super sympa, l'ambiance est chill
Je recommande fortement!
Super concept !! Endroit très convivial, on se sent comme chez soi. Accueil chaleureux, très bonne ambiance!

This is my perfect place to hole up and study when the apartment feels a bit too noisy and when I really need to be productive. You can stay all day, no judgement: there's a microwave to heat up your lunch, you can get food delivered, or just take as much as you want from the table full of plates of cookies, wafers, candy and meringues. They have a toaster too, and all the essentials to make yourself a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. Unlimited coffee, including lattes and cappuccinos (which aren't the best I've ever had, but do their job of caffeinating me), and a very large selection of teas. The staff is very friendly and helpful. They have all sorts of events planned and the first floor can get very noisy, so go to the second floor for silence and a nice view of the Place des Festivals.

Really worth it for a productive day!

Very cool concept! 
This place is much bigger than I thought. The upper floor is a "quiet space" with quite a few isolated study rooms, so it's a great place to study with friends. Anticafé is like a friend's old apartment where you can drop in whenever you want, and freely dig around for snacks. The food mainly consists of toasts, cookies and chips, none of which is very appetizing to me, actually. But the teas and coffees are not bad! The furniture is comfy and eclectic, with some rooms looking like an antique shop. The bathroom upstairs have some sort of disco light, with a funny little cat figurine in the window, next to a note along the lines of: "Don't let him in! He eats all the cookies!" 

The people working there are really nice and cool, and they have an efficient computerized system to track how long you stayed. We came fairly early (around 10 AM), and grabbed a nice old fashioned office desk next to an open window upstairs. The room became gradually more sunny, and more people showed up around lunchtime. We stayed for about 3h, and payed around 15$ for the whole thing. It's a bit expensive considering that we almost didn't eat anything and only a drink each, but the place is so likeable that we didn't mind. Anticafé is not just a coffeeshop and a workplace, it's also a community, with organized events such as language exchange or open mic poetry nights. They keep a weekly calendar of all events in the kitchen. 

A great place to check out if you're looking for a cozy study spot around Place-des-Arts!

The Anti-Café, very cool concept for a café. All the coffee, tea, toast and cookies are free... you pay by the hour to hang out in their "homey" like spaces. It's $3 for your first hour and $2 for every hour after that- billed by the minute. $9 max per day. Sweet deal. This café is also like a vintage thrift shop (no clothes that I could see but trinkets, jewelry, books, decorations and furniture etc. The concept is great and you will enjoy hanging out here from time to time but the ambiance and decor is a little hodgepodge. That might be part of the concept but for my taste a little more style and more careful selection of furniture would make this place more cool and I'd probably return more often. Still a cool place to study, work or play board games with your friends
Highly recommend. Relaxed hipster cafe, where you pay by hour not by drink.

Petite mise à jour du commentaire:
Je suis repassé à l'Anticafé récemment et qu'elle fut ma bonne surprise de voir la différence d'accueil par rapport à la première fois.
Cordial, claire, sympathique et bienveillant, voilà comment je qualifierais ce deuxième 'premier' contact
La cerise sur le gâteau fut ma surprise quand, après avoir raconté brièvement ma première mésaventure à mon arrivée, je fus plus tard approché par l'actuel gérant (Jerry) qui en a eu vent et qui s'est excusé au nom de l'établissement (notons que ce n'est pas de sa faute !) et qui a fait un geste commercial plus qu' appréciable en me démontrant ainsi la véritable façon de gérer un établissement et d'être tout simplement humain.
Je le dis aujourd'hui, je recommande l'Anticafé de la Place de Arts, j'y vais même régulièrement depuis et je suis toujours ravi !
Merci et bravo à vous !
Ps: Je laisse le commentaire précédent, à titre informatif, comme quoi il est très simple de passer de mauvais à très bon !
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Mauvaise expérience dès le premier jour...

A notre arrivée, nous sommes très gentiment invités à visiter par une garçon très cordial à l'accueil.

Nous prenons donc le temps d'enlever nos chaussures pour faire un tour rapide, je précise d'ailleurs bien à notre hôte que nous ne comptons pas rester mais il nous dit que l'on peut quand meme visiter, ce qui est fort aimable.

Mais 2 minutes après, un certain David (gérant apparemment) s'en mêle, parle très mal à son collègue (notre guide) et le renvoie à l'entrée puis se tourne vers nous et nous dit qu'on a pas à être ici, sur un ton plus que malpoli.

Nous constatons en effet qu'il y a du monde, un événement apparemment, nous nous excusons donc poliment en disant qu'on a été invités à visiter et on a la réponse habituelle "si on laissait tout le monde visiter, bla bla..." puis à notre grand étonnement on entend un "Si vous voulez visiter, même 5 min, ce sera quand même 3$ !"

Cher Mr David, je ne sais pas si vous avez entendu parler du service à la clientèle mais c'est le minimum qu'on le se doit de respecter même dans une période de 'rush', on peut perdre un client très facilement à cause de ça, et le rapport humain, surtout pour ce genre d'endroit, est plus important que les bénéfices !

Donc même s'il y a du monde, et j'en suis ravi pour vous, ne prenez pas vos clients pour des malpropres, nous somme tout à fait compréhensibles et nous sommes prêts à céder notre place à ceux qui payent, si c'est ce qui compte le plus pour vous.

Conclusion: deux client mécontents qui ne reviendront pas et une mauvaise revue sur votre établissement.

Nous tenons à saluer notre hôte à la porte qui nous a, lui, très bien accueilli.
Bonne soirée.

Very unique place, with a warm atmsphere. The coffee and snacks are not very good but it is a great environment for studying/working. 
Lots of interesting furniture and other odds and ends, all of which is for sale.

Feels like home (with a lot of roommates!!!)

What an amazing idea; this place charges you for the amount of time you spend there, starting at $3.00 per  hour, to a maximum of $ 9.00,and all the tea, coffee, hot chocolate and biscuits you can consume. Vintage Pyrex cups, vintage '40s music, hodgepodge of teapots, coffeepots, paper plates, and whatever biscuits are there that day. Vintage furniture and objects, interesting art on the wall, and customers coming and going nonstop. Some of the furniture and objects are actually for sale, so if you feel like buying a Victorian- style couch, try here. The art, all original, is also for sale.
On an end note, I have to say this is not an obvious spot, we missed it while walking, there are no tell-tale signs, no distinctive door or window, the cafe is not street level, and once you enter,  climb the stairs, you have to remove your boots and put on the provided slippers,then register your name and time you arrive, your bill will be calculated accordingly. There's also a game room and another where you can watch movies or TV. Great concept, great ambiance, great place.

Awesome place to hang out for the evening and get work done. Wasn't really a fan of the food selection though. I thought it would be more things baked in house but it's really just a bunch of prepackaged cheap snacks.

As an economic model, this café is really interesting and I'll be curious to see how they do over the long term. 
It's like this - imagine with a regular café, you have numerous customers who come to hang out, work, socialize... and spend a few hours doing so while only purchasing one coffee. Look, I've done it, too. This has to cramp the business owner's style, because people are taking up space and not contributing to the cash flow of the business - it's a common café problem. 
Anticafé seems to have very cleverly and amicably figured out a way to not only make people feel welcome and comfortable to stay as long as they like, to do whatever they like, but they also ensure a profit by charging you to be there by the hour, not by the coffee. This works marvelously well, partly because they also have a selection of treats you can choose from as well as teas and espresso-based coffees, and you just pay a very modest lump sum per hour. The other success factor, I think, is that it's set up like somebody's big, communal home - there's a kitchen area and it's serve yourself, plus there are many rooms off the main room, where you can wander in and hunker down on a comfy couch with your book, or you can pull up to a big old dinner table with your laptop to work. Separate rooms are bookable for private meetings. It's a really cool idea. 
I was in on a Friday early evening and by the time I left, it was beginning to feel like somebody's house party. I suspect it has a different feel on different days and times of the week. 
My only real complaint? The having to take your boots off at the door thing - I got really wet and filthy socks from being forced to do this, as several patrons didn't seem to think these rules applied to them. Plus, people are messy (especially in the kitchen) and there are crumbs and whatnot all over the floor. They do offer an assortment of shared slippers to use, but, eh, sorry... NO. 
Other than the sock feet thing, though, it's a beautiful and comfortable spot, and who doesn't like a buffet of animal crackers, cheesies, hummus and Nutella toast with your coffee?

This is a unique place. You basically pay an hourly rate which gives you access to the location. There are about 12 rooms with sofas, tables, TVs,  Wi-Fi. Additionally, there are pretzels, cookies, coffee and tea that you can have at your leisure.

The place is  a little bit noisy, depending on which room that you go in. But there are more quiet rooms that you can enjoy if you're there just to read a book  or study.

I recommend it, as it will become a really fun community.

This is my favourite anti-café so far for sure, maybe because it combines a quiet space to work and have a coffee and chill with my love of secondhand and vintage. I saw mamas breastfeeding on the comfy couches or walking their kiddos around to put them to sleep, and students working on papers, all spread out throughout the spacious rooms and installed on couches or big dining room tables. The guy working when we were there was super kind and chill and had the right balance to deal with vintage hagglers and moms making tea. Super sweet. 

I loved browsing the collection of stuff for sale, I find this kind of hodge podge space full of junk and treasures to be totally inspiring. I can totally see myself spending lots of time here, though I wouldn't come specifically for the cookies since they seem to be of the bulk store bought variety. Hopefully when this place is more established there will be a baker in the coop and some next level treats on offer. I can only see this place getting better.

It'a a great place to study when it's not super packed. The concept is great, you pay for the time you spend there (3$ for the first hour and 2$ for an extra hour until a max of 9$/day) and you have access to coffee/tea and some snacks (chips/cookies/uncooked vegetables and dip). 

However, when it's super packed (mostly near exams periods), you might not find a seat. Also, if you're looking for a place to study in silence, it's not the best spot as people often do team projects.

Finally, their washrooms are pretty dark and have disco lights. I still don't understand why they made that choice but every time I go to the washroom I get small headache.
C'est un beau espace, et un bon lieu pour les étudiants, ou des discussions. Seule problème est que leur Wifi ne marche pas !

J'adore ! Un de mes endroits préférés a Montreal pour étudier ou faire des travaux de groupe ! Il faut mettre des pantoufle  ,alors si vous ne voulez pas utiliser celle du café je vous recommande d'apporter les vôtre. ;)

This place is huge! The entrance was so small, no one notices it. I know this is gonna sound weird, but it really reminded me of the tardis (doctor who), sonce its much bigger on the inside. Unlike regular cafés, you have to make your own drink and go get your own food. They say to make yourself feel at home, which it does except you have to pay. Speaking of that, you pay by hour, not by the drinks or by the biscuits you eat. The only minor thing I didn't really enjoy is that it is a very crowded place.

Anticafe is a really good deal if you want to spend all day working in a cafe. It's about $10 max for a day, including all the tea and cookies you want. The only let down is that the cookies are really not great - they taste like super budget cookies (which is understandable!) so you end up going elsewhere for lunch anyway. 

The seating is good and plentiful, and there are plug sockets everywhere, but the tables are all different so you might not get one that works for you at first.

Pretty smart business model. This cafe is pretty much like going being at home. You can make yourself food, chill on the couches and staying as long as you want. Yes of course there is a trick but it is totally worth it, you sign in when you arrive and you get charge 3$/h with a maximum of 9$. Pretty genius.

Pay by the hour with unlimited drinks and snacks. Entrance is very hidden and a bit sketchy looking on the outside. On the inside, the entrance way is very crowded and it's a bit tough to take off your shoes / put on your shoes with many people coming and going. The place itself is cozy, it's sort of like a home away from home.

Love this place. First time here. Have to register for your stay. Charged hourly up to 9$ maximum (3$ first hour then 2$/h). 

Free drink and snack.

Quiet and comfortable. 

Highly recommended.

This place is great to study with 1 or 2 friends and chill with strangers for the time of a tea cup. The concept is amazingly smart. 

The big neg point is that sometime I think they should improve some few little things like cleaning table more properly and fix some small details like add more electric plugs and lights (useful to study !)

Great relaxing place to go if you enjoy these communal "hipster" environments where there's no fixed menu except for the coffees, you pay by the hour and everything is included. You need to register yourself when you check in and then right there you got the kitchen to grab whatever you want. The second floor is the quiet floor so it's the perfect spot to read or study by yourself. I loved the place and the employees were really nice, but I couldn't stay there much longer because you need to take your boots off due to the snow and the smell of feet was just... unbearable (not the cafe's fault of course). I'll definitely come back after spring.

Absolutely love this place! It has such an interesting concept in terms payment and hospitality. Essentially you pay for the time you spend there, and not for the amount of coffee/tea/food you consume. They have a nice spread of snacks, toast, tea selection, espresso machine, coffee etc. that you can help yourself to, making it a really welcoming and trusting communal experience. The cafe has a combination of more traditional open cafe style seating, with lounge areas and bar type seats, as well as more apartment type areas that break off into small study rooms and seating areas that feel much more private and quiet. It makes it a really great place for working or meeting. Also the staff are just so nice and welcoming. For anyone looking for some Eastern European feel, this place also has a lot of that going on. 
love it.

Interesting idea. You pay by the hour for the time that you're here, but you get all of the coffee (including lattes) and snacks you want at no extra charge. There's a $9 cap on the total charge. Not bad.
